title: England football news: FA 'offer counselling to England players' after racial abuse
text:
The Football Association has reportedly offered counselling to England players after being racially abused during their 6-0 win against Bulgaria on Monday night.

The Three Lions' Euro 2020 qualifier against Bulgaria was marred by racist chanting and the game had to be halted twice by UEFA officials due to the abuse.

All players in the squad for the trip to Sofia were written to by the FA on Tuesday giving them the opportunity to receive support, according to The Times.

The FA has reportedly offered counselling to England players after being racially abused

An agent representing the England side said: 'The manager and the FA were first class in the way they supported the players in Sofia but this shows they take the duty of care very seriously.'

Players can reportedly receive support during the international break in November when England face Montenegro and Kosovo, although counselling is on offer before the next meet.

England debutant Tyrone Mings had complained to referee's assistant Bojan Zobenica that he had been targeted in the 22nd minute of the game and monkey chants were heard whenever Raheem Sterling and Marcus Rashford were on the ball and home fans were seen making Nazi salutes during the match on Monday.

Bulgaria were charged by UEFA on Tuesday evening while the Three Lions also face punishment for disrupting the hosts' national anthem and failing to take enough stewards.

The president of the Bulgarian FA - Borislav Mihaylov - quit on the demand of the country's prime minister following the shocking scenes.
